questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is false regarding a disaster?

options.a: Occurrence that causes damage to life and property
options.b: Occurrence that has the potential to cause disruption or damage to people
options.c: Occurrence that causes deterioration of health and health services
options.d: Occurrence that can cause substantial economic harm

questions.explanation:
A disaster is defined as any occurrence that causes damage, ecological disruption, loss of human 
life, or deterioration of health and health services. It usually requires an extraordinary response 
from outside the affected community or area. 683 
Sold by @itachibot A hazard is any phenomenon that has the potential to cause disruption or damage to people and 
their environment.

questions.question: Question 2: Which type of natural disaster causes the most deaths?
questions.explanation:
Hydrological natural disasters cause the most deaths. The Disaster Information Management System of Deslnventar classifies natural disasters into five 
major categories. They are: • Geophysical - earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcano eruptions • Hydrological - floods, debris flow, and landslides • Meteorological - cyclones, tornadoes, extreme temperatures, sandstorms, blizzards etc. • Climatological - drought, forest wildfire, glacial lake outburst etc. • Biological - epidemics and insect infestations

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.explanation:
The correct order is Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation. Disaster management includes three aspects: 1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows: • Search, rescue, and first-aid • Field care • Triage • Tagging • Identification of dead 2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking 
steps such as: • Water supply • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene • Food safety • Vector control 3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the 
effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in 
disaster-prone areas. 684 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is false about disaster management?

options.a: Measures to prevent hazards are designed in mitigation phase
options.b: Rescue and evacuation occur in recovery phase
options.c: Measures on vector control are done in rehabilitation phase
options.d: Field care and tagging are done in disaster impact and response phase

questions.explanation:
Rescue and evacuation occur in the response phase, not in the recovery phase. Disaster management includes three aspects: 1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows: • Search, rescue, and first-aid • Field care • Triage • Tagging • Identification of dead 2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking 
steps such as: • Water supply • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene • Food safety • Vector control 3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the 
effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or 
disaster-prone areas. 685

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the most common disease after a disaster?
questions.explanation:
Gastroenteritis is the most commonly reported disease after a disaster. It occurs due to contamination of water supply, damage to the sewerage system, overcrowding 
and poor sanitation. Therefore, supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are 
the most practical and effective strategies of disease prevention in the post–disaster period.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following diseases is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period?
questions.explanation: Leishmaniasis is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period. Diseases that are commonly seen in the post-disaster phase are: • Gastroenteritis (most common) • Acute respiratory infections • Leptospirosis • Rickettsiosis • Rabies • Equine encephalitis

questions.question:
Question 7: A district in Andhra Pradesh reported severe drought. Which of the following vitamin 
deficiencies would you expect to see in this population?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin A deficiency is the most common deficiency in areas of famines and droughts. It leads 
to xerophthalmia and blindness. 686 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Following a drought in Bihar, the government launched an immediate mass vaccination 
program. Which of the following vaccines is recommended in such cases?
questions.explanation:
Measles vaccination is recommended for infants and children, immediately following a disaster. 
This should be given along with vitamin A supplementation as measles can exacerbate vitamin A 
deficiency. The vaccination of infants and children against measles is one of the most important public health 
response measures during a humanitarian crisis when less than 90% of the children or an 
unknown percentage have already been vaccinated against measles. Measles and polio vaccines are recommended immediately after an emergency. Option A: Cholera vaccine is not recommended. Option B: Hepatitis A vaccine is recommended at the outset of an outbreak. Option C: Tetanus vaccine is recommended in the early stages and post-emergency stage.

questions.question:
Question 9: Immediately following a disaster, mass vaccination of which of the following vaccines does 
the WHO recommend?
questions.explanation:
The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera, and rabies vaccines for mass vaccination after a 
disaster. However, high-risk populations are recommended to take the cholera vaccine. The rabies 
vaccine is given only for post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.question:
Question 10: You are a field doctor at the site of an earthquake. You assist in rapidly classifying the injured 
on the basis of the likelihood of their survival and need for intervention. What is this process 
called?
questions.explanation:
The process of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and 
likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention is called triage. It is carried out at the site 
of disaster. Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of 
origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.explanation:
In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses. An internationally accepted four-color coded system, with red having the highest priority is used 
commonly here.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is correct about reverse triage?

options.a: Classifying the victims based on the severity of their injuries and their survival with treatment
options.b: Highest preference is given to severely injured patients
options.c: More injured victims are given the lowest preference
options.d: Color coding is done with red as the highest priority.

questions.explanation:
687 
Sold by @itachibot Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are 
injured more. This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle 
soon after treatment. It is also done when there is a scarcity of medical resources after a disaster. The surge capacity of hospitals is increased to accommodate for the natural disaster, by 
discharging non-emergent existing patients. This enables hospitals to allow for an acute increase 
in incoming patients.

questions.question:
Question 13: Triage is done during disaster management to ensure treatment of casualties is done 
properly. What is true about triage done at the disaster site?

options.b: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
options.c: Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
options.d: Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.explanation: Moribund patients receive the lowest priority. This is because despite paying quite a lot of attention, the benefit is still questionable.

questions.question: Question 14: What is the level of residual chlorine to be maintained in the water bodies after a disaster?
questions.explanation:
The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is 0.7-0.9 mg/L. Chlorine is a disinfectant that is added to water bodies. In normal conditions, water should have 
free residual chlorine (FRC) of 0.2 - 0.5 mg/L. However, during a disaster, there is an increased 
risk of fecal contamination of water sources from the sewage systems. Therefore, it is necessary to 
increase FRC to 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following gas was responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy?
questions.explanation:
The gas responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy, which occurred on 3rd December 1984 at the 
Union Carbide Pesticide Plant, was methyl isocyanate.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following emission occurred in Chernobyl explosion accident of 1986?
questions.explanation:
Chernobyl nuclear explosion occurred on 26th April, 1986, in the Soviet Union. It caused the 
release of Iodine-I131, Cesium-Cs134, Cs137, and Strontium-Sr90, and other isotopes into the 
atmosphere.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India?

options.b: Ministry of Environment, Forest, and Climate change

questions.explanation:
The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management at the Centre except 
for dealing with droughts which are under the purview of the Ministry of Agriculture. 688 
Sold by @itachibot Other parts of the Indian government involved in disaster management are the Emergency 
Medical Relief Wing under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The Indian Meteorological Department plays a role in mitigation of disaster and its preparedness.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is a nodal centre in case of disaster management?
questions.explanation:
The district disaster management authority is the nodal center for disaster management. It is chaired by either, the District Collector, District Magistrate or the Deputy Commissioner. The 
Chief Medical Officer of the district is a part of this authority.

questions.question:
Question 19: The NIDM is involved in the mitigation and management of disasters in India. Who is the 
president of this institution?
questions.explanation:
The National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM) is under the Ministry of Home Affairs of 
India. Its president is the Union Home Minister. National Institute of Disaster Management is a premier institute for training and capacity 
development programs for managing natural disasters in India, on a national as well as regional 
basis.

questions.question: Question 20: Who is the chairman of the National Disaster Management Authority of India?
questions.explanation:
National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) is an apex body of the Government of India, 
with a mandate to lay down policies for disaster management. It is chaired by the Prime Minister 
of India. The image given below shows the logo of the NDMA. 689
